column5: I‚Äôve felt similarly. I‚Äôm getting paid still so that‚Äôs not as much of a concern (I could be making more though and my plan to move out this year probably isn‚Äôt happening anymore). Quarantine has given me freedom to do several things, try new hobbies, get chores done, and work on things without having outside life obligations getting in the way. I‚Äôm used to isolating a decent amount, so it isn‚Äôt super different from me. I do miss my friends though cause and some activities, and work actually. But I am content for the most part. My quarantine has kind of ended because work has started up again a little. So we‚Äôll see how the transition goes. But I‚Äôve been enjoying quarantine too, it‚Äôs not just you. It can be freeing to people in the right circumstances. Don‚Äôt feel guilty, your feelings are valid.
That‚Äôs what my favorite water bottle says!
All the resources I found for anorexia mortality rate were 5~%
Holy wow I thought it was painted till I checked the sub. It‚Äôs amazing.

Every time I remember BPD has a 10% mortality rate I get scared. I‚Äôm already in the 70something% that attempts at least once. I think I remember reading BPD is the second or third most deadly mental illness after dissociative identify disorder or schizophrenia. And it scares me.

The problem is you don‚Äôt seem to understand what rape is, so in a way you are appropriating it even if it‚Äôs not your intention. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you‚Äôre in a relationship or how long you‚Äôve been together, you can be married and it is still rape if someone doesn‚Äôt stop when you tell them to. No matter the gender, age, relationship status. If you don‚Äôt stop sex when someone says stop it is rape. And you don‚Äôt have to explicitly say ‚Äústop‚Äù you can say no, take a break, hold on, a million different things. Any type of revoking consent means you stop, or it becomes rape. The lines are very clearly drawn with rape. If consent is not given or if consent is taken away in any manner, it‚Äôs rape. End of story. 

Also, drunk people can‚Äôt legally give consent and no response is not consent and coerced consent is not consent.

Why did you attack me on such a personal level? Jk. In all seriousness I struggled with some specific fuckups for a while because I felt they were unforgivable. They forgave me but I didn‚Äôt forgive myself. It took a lot to fix that.

It‚Äôs called a stem stitch! Just the cross stitches didn‚Äôt look round enough to me so I looked up round stitches to give it a better shape. I‚Äôm also obsessed with 3/4 stitches, I like smoothing smaller stuff to be less jagged.

I like to refer to ‚Äúnormal‚Äù people as ‚Äúneurotypical‚Äù. There really is no ‚Äúnormal‚Äù, but neurotypical basically says that the person has a brain without any diagnosable abnormalities.
I feel like my FPs always start somewhat toxic but I can make them healthy with some therapy. My bf is my FP and we have a healthy relationship.

Oh I know. Your emotional mind is going to keep doing that, for lots of stuff. But if you talk to him, you get an answer. You can stop stewing, because you‚Äôll know. Maybe he‚Äôs struggling with understanding, maybe he‚Äôs doing it accidentally and doesn‚Äôt even notice. You won‚Äôt know unless you ask. I‚Äôve said I love you to my boyfriend since month 2 of our relationship. It‚Äôs been 2 and a half years now and he still hasn‚Äôt said it and you bet your ass I stewed over that the entire time and it drove me insane. We finally actually talked about it and apparently he sees love differently than I do. He sees it as a commitment like getting engaged, and he‚Äôs not ready for that. I‚Äôm not either, getting engaged wise, or even moving in, we‚Äôre not ready. But he sees love differently. I say it to my friends, I have so much love to give, but he‚Äôs not like that and now I understand. And we have an agreement I can keep saying it because I need to express it, and he knows I won‚Äôt expect it back so he can enjoy it without guilt. But I wouldn‚Äôt have known if we didn‚Äôt talk about it. We had several conversations actually, to get to this understanding, but I have such a sense of peace now because I know why. I know he loves me, but he‚Äôs not ready to say it and I‚Äôm ok with that. I see love in the way he acts. My emotional mind is soothed because it doesn‚Äôt have to constantly wonder anymore.

At least he‚Äôs putting effort in? Honestly you guys need to have a conversation about it. You should never let anything stew unsaid. Just ask him why he‚Äôs started doing it for everyone. I know from experience, stewing over important things like this can lead to resentment and assumptions when there are sometimes simple explanations.
Ahhhhh the height of the BPD rollercoaster. I gotcha. Made my own share of heightened BPD posts. I home you feel better though
Friends who haven‚Äôt asked to be called ‚Äúthey‚Äù?

My last (5th) hospitalization was after my last (2nd) suicide attempt. For a while I was working hard on being better, but I think part of it was trying to convince my boyfriend I was better and we should get back together. We did, but in the time we weren‚Äôt talking I don‚Äôt think I had an FP, but it was very lonely. Some of the things I worked on did stick, but some didn‚Äôt. Regardless I‚Äôm still leagues ahead of how I‚Äôd ever been before. But I think if I‚Äôm ever in a relationships they‚Äôll always be my FP. Do you think it can be natural, for your partner to be your FP? I feel like even normal people have their partner as their unofficial FP.

To be honest, it‚Äôs repetition. You just keep rationalizing and rationalizing and eventually it starts to stick. It‚Äôs like building a muscle. It‚Äôs crazy hard, I know. But I just tell myself he has his own life and responsibilities. I‚Äôve been with him long enough and we‚Äôve been through enough that I know he‚Äôd never cheat on me. And I know he loves me, even if he doesn‚Äôt say it. You don‚Äôt stay with someone after they attempt if you don‚Äôt love them.  So really every time I wonder why he hasn‚Äôt responded for a while, I‚Äôm like he‚Äôs probably napping. He likes naps. And he has a lot of schoolwork, or when he‚Äôs at work he can‚Äôt really talk. My obsessive thoughts still keep coming, maybe a bit less, I just got better at dismissing them. Like oh boy, my brains being a dick again. No he‚Äôs not ignoring you he‚Äôs just doing x, y, or z. If it gets hard I invest myself in something so I‚Äôm distracted.
Isn‚Äôt that a good thing? Not assuming anyone‚Äôs gender?

How.... how can you just not have an FP? Like, legit question. I automatically get a new one if I lose mine, like I‚Äôll latch onto a friend if not a romantic partner. How do you just not have an FP? How does one go about that?
I‚Äôve tried journaling but it just doesn‚Äôt work for me. It‚Äôs weird. I‚Äôm not sure why. It‚Äôs just like yea, those are my feelings, sitting there, whatever.

Yes, it‚Äôs often a huge part of BPD. You might‚Äôve heard of ‚Äúsplitting‚Äù before, it‚Äôs the same thing. Our brains are very all or nothing, partly because we tend to go to extremes for everything. So we meet a new person and they can be great maybe our new BFF and then we learn about something bad about them or a thing they did and suddenly all of that good is invalidated and they‚Äôre on our permanent shit list. Personally black and white thinking is incredibly pervasive for me, it leaks into everything. Even situations, I can never see gray areas. I can try to think between two extremes and make a gray area, but most of the time I literally can‚Äôt do it. Then my therapist will go ‚Äúwell how about x gray area‚Äù and it‚Äôs like a magic trick how she seemingly pulls this gray area out of nowhere. And I‚Äôll be like oh wow that makes a lot of sense that‚Äôs better, but couldn‚Äôt come up with it myself. It‚Äôs a self defense mechanism we developed to try and protect ourselves. If we already hate the thing it can‚Äôt hurt us. 

To quote the second diagnostic criteria for BPD from the DSM: ‚ÄúA pattern of unstable and intense interpersonal relationships characterized by extremes between idealization and devaluation (also known as "splitting")‚Äù  . 

Here‚Äôs an article that might explain it better than me: https://www.priorygroup.com/blog/understanding-splitting-in-borderline-personality-disorder

I‚Äôm so sorry to hear you‚Äôre hurting, but I hope this leads you to a better place. People can love each other and not be good for each other. Try to take the time to focus on yourself, but I know it can be hard to be alone. You‚Äôll find someone eventually, someone whose personality complements yours, and someone who also knows that relationships are work that‚Äôs worth it.
Please tell me you‚Äôre joking. Please.
I hate that I can‚Äôt see people as both. My black and white thinking is always so bad it‚Äôs either or. I wish I could not only see the best or worse in people. It blows.

My therapist and I have talked about the same thing, but our terms are Child Self and Cynic Self. The child self is my innocence, the pure good in me. The cynic self is, well, the cynic. It trusts no one, and has been taught the childish joy is stupid and wrong. But it still has to protect child self because no one else will. And it‚Äôs usually one or the other, not both at the same time, because black and white thinking is a bitch.

It always feels impossible. And then somehow you keep going, and it sucks for a while, but then it slowly becomes possible. If it comes to a breakup, and if your friends or family are supportive, try to stay around them to keep yourself safe. Support systems are vital.
I vacuumed and then used rubbing alcohol. It was a pale pink but like the entire container, so most of it came out but not all. Thank god it‚Äôs not white carpet.

Crap I‚Äôm an INFJ, I didn‚Äôt know that and hope it‚Äôs not true xD. There‚Äôs definitely connection between our personalities and our disorders. The point I was trying to make is that personalities don‚Äôt cause it, and the illness doesn‚Äôt define your personality. I‚Äôm a sensitive person too. My brother and I went through the same circumstances but he came out absolutely fine because things don‚Äôt affect him as much. But me being sensitive isn‚Äôt what‚Äôs most responsible for my BPD. The abuse and emotional neglect with how I was raised, and other circumstances led me to have BPD more than any part of my personality. So yea there‚Äôs connection, but it doesn‚Äôt condemn who you are.

I understand. I‚Äôve been there, I know all of those feelings. I know it‚Äôs hard to think about this right now, but it‚Äôs not you. It is NOT you. It‚Äôs them. Sometimes breakups happen and they don‚Äôt give you a reason why they fell out of love. Sometimes they don‚Äôt even know. But it‚Äôs them, it‚Äôs their problems or feelings. And as for your current relationship, you NEED to talk to them about this. Communication is the single most important thing in a relationship with a BPD person. Unfortunately it‚Äôs also usually very hard. You need to tell him how your feeling. Ask what‚Äôs going on. Being in this uncertain state of limbo is giving you so much stress and you see the toll it takes. My current relationship is the healthiest I‚Äôve ever had. My boyfriend and I learned together how to communicate and have an actual healthy relationship. Sometimes when I need to talk to him about something but I‚Äôm nervous, I‚Äôll sit there and open and close my mouth for like 10 minutes until I can shove the words out. He understands, he knows what I‚Äôm doing, and he waits patiently for me to be able to say it. And then we talk. And a really helpful mindset we‚Äôre in is it‚Äôs us against the problem. Not me vs him, us vs the problem. Sometimes communication gets tangled and we have to step back and explain, but we talk about it. I don‚Äôt have to sit in uncertain terror, constantly afraid we‚Äôre going to break up anymore. Two and a half years has gotten me to a place where when we have a problem, I think ‚Äúokay, we need to talk about it‚Äù instead of ‚Äúthis is how it ends‚Äù. We‚Äôve been through some pretty traumatic shit together, and we‚Äôre not breaking up for anything that doesn‚Äôt deserve it. If we break up, it‚Äôll be for a damn good reason. But whatever it is, you need to talk. You need to tell them your feelings and where you‚Äôre at so they can respond, because they can‚Äôt read your mind. 

TL;DR- You need to communicate. It‚Äôs the most vital thing in a relationship. Yea, it‚Äôs hard and scary to talk, but you have to.

From the other things I‚Äôve studied, borderline was supposedly named that because it‚Äôs the line between neurotic and psychotic. Once you introduce actual psychosis symptoms wouldn‚Äôt that kind of invalidate it? Also, do you have a link to that part of the DSM? I‚Äôve never seen the part about hallucinations before!

Yea I‚Äôve read that study before, the only comorbid disorder they were looking at was PTSD. They said if they were allowed to consider more, then people with BPD and hallucinations would probably be in a subgroup of a more severe personality disorder. The 37% of those with hallucinations that didn‚Äôt meet PTSD might have other comorbid disorders they didn‚Äôt look into.

Have you guys heard people say hallucinations are part of BPD? I know there was a meme spreading on Facebook about it. From all the articles I‚Äôve read, and what my therapist said, hallucinations are not part of BPD. Like mania, they‚Äôre caused by a comorbid disorder. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôve read, anyway, but I was wondering if anyone else had done research on the topic as well.
Yea FPs can be dangerous sometimes because your mood can be based on theirs, and that gives them a control that can be devastating. Learning to separate your feelings/issues from theirs is vital.

I relate to you. I sometimes feel like I didn‚Äôt struggle as much as others. Like my dad was abusive, but at least he didn‚Äôt beat me. The thing about trauma is that it‚Äôs subjective. What‚Äôs traumatic to one person doesn‚Äôt affect another. That‚Äôs why siblings from the same circumstances don‚Äôt have the same diagnoses. My brother is fine, 0 mental illnesses, while I have 10. That genetics theory, like how some people are just born more sensitive than others, definitely has some merit. He just adapted better than I did. This isn‚Äôt the trauma olympics though, and it‚Äôs hurtful to pit traumas against each other. Yours, whatever it is, is valid.

A degree may not trump an opinion but a fact does. It‚Äôs a fact that BPD itself does not include mania. If someone has BPD and they also have mania, then they have another illness causing the mania. They have similar symptoms, but they‚Äôre fundamentally different.

Cure is typically defined as eliminating a disease, aka it‚Äôs completely gone, or no longer afflicts you at all. For me, one symptom I‚Äôd say I‚Äôm cured of is unstable sense of identity. I know who I am now and what kind of person I am, my sense of self is very stable. But one symptom that my therapist has told me isn‚Äôt curable is my fear of abandonment and from what I‚Äôve seen and read she‚Äôs right. It‚Äôs incredibly deeply ingrained and I‚Äôll be managing it for the rest of my life.
You never have flare ups? Ever? You‚Äôre not still managing anything it‚Äôs just all gone?

When you interact with people with BPD it‚Äôs bound to be bumpy. Interpersonal relationship issues is part of the diagnostic criteria. Many of us have trouble communicating, so when it‚Äôs multiple people with BPD there‚Äôs a lot of crossed wires.

You can have treatment go well enough that you eventually lose enough diagnostic criteria to no longer be diagnosable with BPD. But there are several criteria that aren‚Äôt curable and no matter how much you treat them they will never entirely go away. They can be managed but not cured. Remission is basically defined as a decrease in intensity/severity of symptoms so it is kind of relative, which is probably causing the debates because many people think of it like it just goes away completely.
Me too. It‚Äôs been spread in several Facebook groups and then you gotta do damage control :/

Are you doing it by yourself, or with a therapist? If you‚Äôre doing it by yourself it has to be harder. It‚Äôs difficult to teach yourself something you don‚Äôt understand.
If you need to be honest with anyone it‚Äôs yourself (and your therapist). The honesty helps you see exactly what‚Äôs going on, and only then can you change it.
I second all of this.

You‚Äôre not a bad person. We are not bad people. Are we great people? Probably not. There aren‚Äôt really words for this gray area. 

But a lot of this isn‚Äôt your fault. You didn‚Äôt choose for your brain to develop this way. You didn‚Äôt choose these distorted thinking patterns or mood instability or fear of abandonment. You know why I think you‚Äôre a good person? Because you want to be better. Bad people don‚Äôt want to be better. Bad people think they‚Äôre fine when they‚Äôre not. 

And this isn‚Äôt making excuses. These are reasons. The difference is responsibility. Excuses take no responsibility while reasons take responsibility and explain. 

This self awareness you have is amazing. It will be a really valuable tool. Try to see a therapist that specializes in BPD so they know how to treat your problems best. As long as you‚Äôre honest with yourself and aware, you will improve <3
You‚Äôre all fantastic. Thank you. These puns are so apeeling

Yea I read women in their 30s have better mental health when they have kids so I‚Äôm waiting till then for that. But my meds have mostly stabilized my emotions at least. Major problems for me are dysfunctional thinking patterns and schemas, so I‚Äôd like to try and fix those before my mind settles
I‚Äôm 23 so pretty settled already, at least out of the teenage danger zone haha.

Yup! I‚Äôve been in therapy for BPD specifically for about 3 years, and I‚Äôve gone from all 9 criteria down to 6. I know there are some that will never go away and I‚Äôll always deal with them, but it gets easier.

BPD can‚Äôt be cured, but a job might help you. For some people (myself included) it can provide structure. Have a set scheduled can help make life a bit easier and being less anxiety. 

As for the identity stuff, that comes with time. I used to have it bad, but now I actually don‚Äôt have that criteria anymore! I started collecting all these bits of me, like puzzle pieces, and fitting them together to make a picture. Like I‚Äôm kind and funny and hardworking. I‚Äôm an INFJ, an empath, and an ambivert. It takes time to really feel identity, but you can get there. 

On jobs and educations, start with something you love. There‚Äôs gotta be something you love ;) I liked cooking. I liked that I was good at it and it made other people happy. That‚Äôs how I got started in culinary. Maybe you like art, there‚Äôs a gazillion ways that could go. Maybe you‚Äôre really good at puzzles, something like engineering or mechanics. Good at advocating for people? Social services. Don‚Äôt be afraid to try things! You‚Äôre allowed to get a job, not like it, and quit. But try to base your career on something you like, that‚Äôs how you can enjoy it.
BPD can never be cured, but it can be managed to a point where the effects are minimal.

It is an illness. It is NOT your personality. That‚Äôs a common misconception used to shame people with ‚Äúpersonality disorders‚Äù. There is no cure to it, that‚Äôs true, and you do have to alter your thinking and behavior. But it does not mean your personality is bad. 

This article might help: https://www.heretohelp.bc.ca/infosheet/borderline-personality-disorder

Yea and stopping overtime is hard because you kind of teach yourself ‚ÄúI have to work a lot of hours and always be productive‚Äù and then when you realize it‚Äôs harmful and stop you have to teach yourself that you shouldn‚Äôt feel shame or guilt for not being constantly busy or productive.
While I agree with the first sentiment, you can‚Äôt cure BPD or make it go away.

You can‚Äôt cure BPD. You can‚Äôt. It‚Äôs not possible. You can learn to cope with it and correct though patterns and behaviors, enough that you can reduce your diagnostic criteria to the point where you technically don‚Äôt meet them, but some of them will never go away, and you‚Äôll be coping with them for your entire life. The abandonment issues, for example. If you have that, it will never be cured. But you can learn to manage it to the point where it‚Äôs not a problem. 

This is hard to hear and accept. I‚Äôm struggling with it. But I‚Äôve already made a lot of progress so I have to accept it. 

Mental illnesses can not be cured.

I HATE when people try to say those with BPD are narcissists. It‚Äôs quite literally the opposite, we usually think we‚Äôre shit. We‚Äôre constantly seeking validation to prove to ourselves that we‚Äôre not shit. We‚Äôre not trying to prove to ourselves that we‚Äôre great, we‚Äôre just trying to prove that we‚Äôre not absolute garbage. BPD is often a collective clusterfuck of maladaptive coping. We developed ways to get our needs met when we were young, like ‚Äútemper tantrums‚Äù, silent treatment, passive aggressiveness, so called ‚Äúmanipulative‚Äù behavior. They were all unconscious ways of meeting our needs. Unfortunately, they don‚Äôt work the same for grown ups as they did for kids, so now we often look immature. For me a lot of my therapy has been unlearning those inappropriate, unhealthy behaviors. 

TL;DR- BPD is pretty much the opposite of narcissism, we‚Äôre trying to prove we don‚Äôt suck, not that we‚Äôre awesome.

Psychological and emotional neglect can be trauma! Trauma is extremely subjective, whats trauma to someone might be totally fine for someone else.

Yes, this is one of the most common symptoms of BPD! If you look up the part of the brain affected by BPD, you‚Äôll see our amygdalas (responsible for emotion regulation) are very underdeveloped. We never learned emotional maturity, so we‚Äôre kind of stuck with the emotion regulation of a 12-year-old. This is also because those emotional reactions served us when we were younger, they got our needs met, so we kept those reactions, not knowing that they‚Äôre not acceptable for adults. They worked back then, but they don‚Äôt now, and it‚Äôs hard to learn to change a pattern you‚Äôve had your whole life. 

If your family has a hard time understanding BPD (or any mental illness) I‚Äôve found showing them the scientific facts helps. You can see a broken bone with a scan, and you can see brain abnormalities as well. There are studies and pictures of BPD brains out there, so they can see part of our brains aren‚Äôt developed, and it might help them understand that we‚Äôre not crazy and it‚Äôs not something wrong with our personality like the name suggests. It‚Äôs a legitimate, often misunderstood illness, with physical markers. 

Personally, I used this thing called Vital Tones, they have a sound wave treatment for BPD. Sounds sketchy, but it really worked for me, thoroughly enough that there‚Äôs no chance of it being a placebo. Listening to it helped strengthen my emotional regulation a lot. I still have moments but now they‚Äôre more situational than the constant BPD mood swing roller coaster. The first time I used it was right before I got pulled over for speeding for the first time. Instead of having a panic attack or crying, I was calmer and handled the interaction well. My parents jaws were literally dropped because I‚Äôd never reacted like that before and they were so confused as to how I wasn‚Äôt a sobbing mess. So yea, highly recommend for help with emotional regulation!
*insert gif of spongebob doing the rainbow thing* black and white thinking!

Yea! It‚Äôs normal! Here‚Äôs some science about crying: your tears a basically excess emotions! There are several kinds of tears, including emotional. Emotional tears actually contain the excess emotion chemicals. When we get too much emotion, no matter what it is, our body can‚Äôt contain it so it cries it out! That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs always better to let yourself cry, your body is trying to help you out. That‚Äôs also why you might feel better after a good cry. It can be really difficult for BPD people seeing as we always have excess emotion. And it can be a struggle when we feel like it invalidates our emotion. Crying when you‚Äôre super fucking pissed can make it feel like your anger is weakened, when it‚Äôs actually the opposite. You‚Äôre so damn pissed you‚Äôve sprung a leak, that much anger can‚Äôt fit inside! 
I‚Äôve also had some frustrating experiences. I‚Äôve had multiple emotions that don‚Äôt fit, one time I was angry but the anger thing was also kind of funny so I started laughing and crying while looking pissed. Freaked some people out, but I explained and they understood better. 
Hope this can help!

Annie‚Äôs white cheddar shells just add actual white cheddar to it. 

Also a fettuccini Alfredo that‚Äôs not from a can, basically equal parts cream cheese, milk, Parmesan, and butter. Add some garlic and salt, nice and thick and comforting. 

Also there‚Äôs a lemon garlic seasoning (lemon garlic garni is what I get) but find a good seasoning salt and give flavor to random things. Microwave steam green beans, add lemon, evoo, and season salt they‚Äôre damn tasty. Plain pasta, butter, Parmesan, and the seasoning elevates it to flavortown.

I have tried and failed to find a mental illness he‚Äôs got. He‚Äôs fine. I have 10, I shit you not, 10 mental illnesses. I think I was born too sensitive or something like that, everything we went through hit me way harder than him. It is what it is, but I‚Äôd be lying if I said I didn‚Äôt envy him just a little.
